unnormalised: ## My Chai Secrets: A Measured Approach
normalised: ## My Chai Secrets: A Measured Approach

unnormalised: Growing up in my Nani's kitchen in Jaipur, measurements were never precise. It was always "a pinch of this" and "a handful of that." But when I moved to Mumbai for college, and had to fend for myself, I quickly realized that a little precision goes a long way, especially when it comes to chai.
normalised: Growing up in my Nani's kitchen in Jaipur, measurements were never precise. It was always "a pinch of this" and "a handful of that." But when I moved to Mumbai for college, and had to fend for myself, I quickly realized that a little precision goes a long way, especially when it comes to chai.

unnormalised: My early attempts at chai were, let's just say, experiments in culinary disaster. One time, I added 200 ml of milk to what was supposed to be a strong, black tea and ended up with something that resembled dishwater. Another time, I got carried away with the ginger, grating a whole 50 g piece into a small saucepan - it was spicy enough to make a grown man cry!
normalised: My early attempts at chai were, let's just say, experiments in culinary disaster. One time, I added two hundred milliliter of milk to what was supposed to be a strong, black tea and ended up with something that resembled dishwater. Another time, I got carried away with the ginger, grating a whole fifty gram piece into a small saucepan - it was spicy enough to make a grown man cry!

unnormalised: That's when I started paying attention to the measurements. My Nani always said, "beta, cooking is an art, but baking is a science." Chai, I decided, was somewhere in between. It needed both creativity and a good understanding of quantities.
normalised: That's when I started paying attention to the measurements. My Nani always said, "beta, cooking is an art, but baking is a science." Chai, I decided, was somewhere in between. It needed both creativity and a good understanding of quantities.

unnormalised: So, I started experimenting. I began with a base of 1 tsp of tea leaves per cup of water. I found that using 1.5 g of good quality Assam tea gave me the perfect strength. It's amazing how such a small amount can make such a big difference.
normalised: So, I started experimenting. I began with a base of one teaspoon of tea leaves per cup of water. I found that using one point five gram of good quality Assam tea gave me the perfect strength. It's amazing how such a small amount can make such a big difference.

unnormalised: Milk was another challenge. Too much, and the chai became bland. Too little, and it was bitter. Eventually, I settled on a ratio of 1:3, milk to water. So, for every 100 ml of water, I would add 300 ml of milk. It created a creamy, rich texture that was just divine.
normalised: Milk was another challenge. Too much, and the chai became bland. Too little, and it was bitter. Eventually, I settled on a ratio of one to three, milk to water. So, for every one hundred milliliter of water, I would add three hundred milliliter of milk. It created a creamy, rich texture that was just divine.

unnormalised: Sugar was a tricky one, too. I tried using a sugar substitute, but it never tasted quite right. Finally, I decided that a small indulgence was worth it. 1 tbsp of sugar per cup of chai seemed to hit the sweet spot. Although, sometimes, on a particularly sweet-craving day, I'd bump it up to 15g.
normalised: Sugar was a tricky one, too. I tried using a sugar substitute, but it never tasted quite right. Finally, I decided that a small indulgence was worth it. One tablespoon of sugar per cup of chai seemed to hit the sweet spot. Although, sometimes, on a particularly sweet-craving day, I'd bump it up to fifteen gram.

unnormalised: For the spices, I discovered that less is more. A small piece of ginger, about 2 cm long, grated finely, was perfect. A pinch of cardamom, around 0.25 tsp, added a subtle aroma that filled the whole kitchen. And a tiny, almost invisible, amount of cinnamon (0.1 tsp) completed the blend.
normalised: For the spices, I discovered that less is more. A small piece of ginger, about two centimeter long, grated finely, was perfect. A pinch of cardamom, around zero point two five teaspoon, added a subtle aroma that filled the whole kitchen. And a tiny, almost invisible, amount of cinnamon (zero point one teaspoon) completed the blend.

unnormalised: Over time, I've adapted my chai recipe depending on my mood and the weather. On a rainy Mumbai morning, I might add an extra 0.5 cm of ginger to warm me up. In the summer, I might reduce the milk to 250 ml per cup for a lighter, more refreshing drink.
normalised: Over time, I've adapted my chai recipe depending on my mood and the weather. On a rainy Mumbai morning, I might add an extra zero point five centimeter of ginger to warm me up. In the summer, I might reduce the milk to two hundred and fifty milliliter per cup for a lighter, more refreshing drink.

unnormalised: Now, my chai is something I'm truly proud of. It's not just a drink; it's a ritual, a moment of peace in the chaos of city life. And it all started with understanding the importance of a few simple measurements.
normalised: Now, my chai is something I'm truly proud of. It's not just a drink; it's a ritual, a moment of peace in the chaos of city life. And it all started with understanding the importance of a few simple measurements.

unnormalised: So, the next time you make chai, don't be afraid to get a little scientific. A little precision can go a long way in creating the perfect cup. And who knows, you might even discover your own secret ingredient, measured just so. Remember 2.5 cm ginger is too much, 1.7 cm is just right (for me!).
